p.s: The question about ShakespearesShakespeare's relevancyrelevance today and wetherwhether or not he should be taught in schools is frequently discussed around the world.
That is why I will be discussing the statement Shakespeare never grows old.He continues to inspire each new generation, by Norman J. Lund.
I think this statement holds true for a long time now, but it nevertheless does not mean that Shakespeare should be taught in school.
It is certainly true that ShakespearesShakespeare's pieces have time and time inspired people around the world.
This can be attributed to the topics Shakespeare writes about, which all are of timeless essence like for example tragic love in Romeo and Juliet or greed for power in Macbeth.

These topics are part of the human existence which makes them relevant throughout all times, but this also gives ShakespearesShakespeare's works the ability to be adapted to all kinds of settings and not just the original ones.
While a lot of the great characteristics of these works can be attributed to ShakespearesShakespeare's skill in writing, this doesn't mean one should only focus on the languangelanguage he uses.
This is however what a lot of schools do, they focus on teaching the students how to analyze ShakespearesShakespeare's writings.
This however takes away the focus from the stories, which were meant to be watched and not interpreted, leaving behind a lot of cultural value contained in these pieces.
Especially for students in non-English speaking countries it is questionable wetherwhether students benefit from analyzing the oftentimes even for native English speakers hard to understand writings.
Rather, such a heavy task would be better fitting in literature or theatre class, which are more specialized on such topics.
One cannot however deny neither the proficiency with which Shakespeare writes, nor the cultural and language-historic value his pieces contain.

This is why I think that even though ShakespearesShakespeare's works might be a seriously hard topic for most students in school, the value they hold is too large to not teach them, so while not abandoning them, schools should definitely redesign the way Shakespeare gets taught, in order to properly get the important cultural and language-historic content across to students instead of dwelling on topics like scene analysis.
